transcript.text: How well can you recognize unfair competition?

contentText.text: How well can you recognize unfair competition? Connect some examples of unfair competition with the type of agreement that’s occurring.

instructionText.text: Select an item from the first column, then drag the arrows to its matching type of unfair competition in the second. When you're done, click on submit.
Click on the question marks to learn more.
Click on Next (bottom right arrow) to continue.

tab.text: Two competitors meet for lunch. One agrees to concentrate sales efforts in the north of the country while the other will focus on the south.

Three competitors who serve the same small market sit down to plan the upcoming year. They review upcoming tenders and agree to take turns as the lowest bidder while the others keep prices too high to be considered.

tab.leftIcon: Senior sales execs at a trade conference
tab.dragIcon: Senior sales execs at a trade conference
tab.text: At a trade conference, several senior-level sales executives discuss how the largest supplier in their market has been unfairly raising prices. They agree that they will reduce their orders substantially – or cancel them completely when possible – and seek another supplier until prices go back down.
A group of competitors in an industry where the price of raw materials is rising have an informal agreement not to allow customer discounts of more than 10%.

tab.rightIcon: Two business people collaborating on a bid
Group deciding to boycott a customer to punish them

optfeedback.text: Dividing customers or territories – known as market allocation – happens when competitors agree to split up customers, products or geographical areas. Doing this reduces competition within the specified areas, and reduces customer options.
Bid rigging occurs when competitors coordinate their bids to influence the outcome of the bidding process.

A company, acting alone, generally has the right to choose whom to do business with. But when two or more companies agree not to do business with another company, their boycott may violate competition laws.
Price fixing involves an agreement between competitors to coordinate their prices or other competitive terms, instead of competing freely and independently against one another.
